I first note that under my own values the current offer would give me

  Item 1: 2 units × 18 = 36  
  Item 2: 3 units × 28 = 84  
  Item 3: 2 units × 70 = 140  
  Item 4: 1 unit × 4 = 4  
  Item 5: 2 units × 91 = 182  

for a total deal‐value of 36 + 84 + 140 + 4 + 182 = 446. 
Since my private outside option is 773 (and a deal made later would be discounted by 0.98 per extra round), getting 446 for sure is very unattractive.

Because I am Player 2 I now have the opportunity to propose a counteroffer. (A counteroffer amounts to stating what bundle to give Player 1; I then “keep” the remainder of each item’s total.) My overall total value (if I took everything) would be 1057. Thus, to get at least as much as my outside option I must secure for myself a bundle with value at least 773. However, if we delay a round the eventual deal’s undiscounted value should be slightly higher so that after applying the discount factor (gamma = 0.98 in round 2) I still match my reservation of 773. In fact, if a deal is reached in round 2 the deal’s overall value is multiplied by 0.98, so I want my “raw” (undiscounted) share to be at least about 773/0.98 ≈ 789.8. (I round this target up to 790.) 

In other words, if I “keep” a bundle with raw value 790, then a deal accepted in the next round will give me 790 × 0.98 ≈ 774—just above my outside offer. 

Let the counteroffer be defined by a 5‐element list [a, b, c, d, e] that represents the numbers of units of items 1–5 that I would give to Player 1; I then get the remainder (since the totals are 3, 5, 3, 4, 7 respectively). My share’s value is 

  18 × (3 – a) + 28 × (5 – b) + 70 × (3 – c) + 4 × (4 – d) + 91 × (7 – e). 

I require that this sum equals 790. Equivalently, the “cost” (the value I give up by conceding units to Player 1) is 

  18a + 28b + 70c + 4d + 91e = 1057 – 790 = 267.

A quick search for a feasible (and “small‐concession” for Player 1) solution leads to the following: set 
  a = 2, b = 5, c = 0, d = 0, and e = 1.
Then
  18×2 = 36  
  28×5 = 140  
  70×0 = 0  
  4×0 = 0  
  91×1 = 91  
and the total concession equals 36 + 140 + 0 + 0 + 91 = 267. 

Under this counteroffer I would get the remainder:
  Item 1: 3 – 2 = 1 unit  (1×18 = 18)  
  Item 2: 5 – 5 = 0 units  (0×28 = 0)  
  Item 3: 3 – 0 = 3 units  (3×70 = 210)  
  Item 4: 4 – 0 = 4 units  (4×4 = 16)  
  Item 5: 7 – 1 = 6 units  (6×91 = 546)  
with a total raw value of 18 + 0 + 210 + 16 + 546 = 790. 

(If Player 1 accepts in the next round the outcome will be discounted by 0.98, but then I would obtain about 774 – just over my outside option.)

Since the current offer gives me only 446 and waiting offers me a possibility at least as good as my reservation, I will not ACCEPT the current offer and will instead propose the counteroffer described.

Thus, my action is:

In any counteroffer I’d be leaving at most 114 worth of my value for Player 1. Step‐by‐step reasoning:

1. My private values for the 5 item types are: 45, 87, 44, 91, and 57 per unit respectively; the available quantities are 2, 4, 4, 3, and 7. If I got every unit, I’d have a total “raw” value of 
  2×45 + 4×87 + 4×44 + 3×91 + 7×57 = 90 + 348 + 176 + 273 + 399 = 1286.

2. My private outside offer is 1187. (This is my “reservation value” – if no agreement is reached I get 1187.)

3. In any negotiated deal the value is discounted only by γ^(r–1). Since we are in round 1, no discount applies. Thus for any deal to be acceptable for me it must yield at least 1187 in my evaluation.

  [1, 1, 4, 2, 1].

  1×45 + 1×87 + 4×44 + 2×91 + 1×57 = 45 + 87 + 176 + 182 + 57 = 547.
 Clearly 547 is far less than my reservation of 1187.

5. In a counteroffer I would be proposing how to split the 5 types of items (by specifying the number of units that Player 1 will get, while I get the remainder). Because my total “pie” value (1286) is only 99 points above 1187, if I want to guarantee that I do at least as well as my outside offer then I may have to “give away” at most roughly 99 of my value. This very limited surplus leaves little room to “buy” Player 1’s consent.

6. In fact, from my perspective I could only offer Player 1 bundles whose value (according to my numbers) is at most 99. But even if I could “cherry‐pick” items that might be relatively more valuable to them, it is extremely unlikely that a bundle worth only 99 in my evaluation would be accepted by Player 1 if, for example, his own outside offer turns out to be substantially better (and his outside offer is drawn over a range up to his total possible value). In short, any counteroffer that guarantees me at least 1187 on my side would leave Player 1 with so little that we would almost certainly fail to agree.

7. Given that the current offer gives me only 547 (far below 1187) and any counteroffer that leaves me with at least 1187 is almost certainly unacceptable to the other side, my best course of action is to WALK and secure my outside offer of 1187, which (at round 1 with no discount) is clearly better than any deal on the table or any counteroffer I can credibly make.

Thus, my action is to WALK.
